pros: Great relationship with professors Flexible hours
cons: Pay and amount of hours allowed to work

pros: The interaction with the students was rewarding, and there was almost no direct supervision-- they just trusted me to do my job in the best way I could for each student.
cons: The job was only part-time, and they wouldn't let me go full time because they would have had to offer benefits. Unfortunately, even part-time meant working there four days a week, which doesn't leave a lot of time to get a second job.

job_title: Alumni Relations Manager in Providence, RI
pros: The campus was small enough to know many people in different departments and there was a lot of opportunity to be involved in other opportunities.
cons: Lack of advancement opportunities within department and salary was low.

pros: Everyone I work with is great, I love our students, Summer Fridays are a plus
cons: No raise in sight, poor communication across departments

job_title: Associate Professor in North Miami Beach, FL
pros: Former reputation Faculty and Students
cons: Poor leadership Culture changed for the worse

review_title: University showing struggle with academic and financial integrity
pros: Location, employees, original purpose, founding women.
cons: The CEO is toxic and out of touch and does not follow the original spirit that the university was founded on. She is not student centered and does not provide a healthy work environment.

review_title: Great fit for students working on a degree
pros: friendly work environment, good hours, relevant job descriptions. for the flexibility of school work the pay is fair.
cons: for student part time jobs the pay is very basic $1,900 a month isn't livable wages for a student, but its better than nothing.

pros: Looks after its employee's with team building and rewards
cons: No cons at this time

pros: The JWU HR Department is one of the best HR Departments I have ever worked for. They make it a priority to do things the right way and set an example of what a high performing HR Department looks like. There are opportunities to learn and improve and the head of HR is someone who I look up to and admire.
cons: The HR Department would benefit greatly if they were to move from a paper filing system to electronic. It would save so much time and effort.

job_title: Assistant Professor in North Miami, FL
pros: Many opportunities for additional earnings
cons: Base salary is low for the role

pros: Good employee benefits and time off
cons: Not a lot of room for growth

review_title: They will not take care of the students and are there for your money
pros: If you want to work in a private university that doesn't set up their students for success and pass them along to get their money. Johnson & Wales is the place for you!
cons:
Johnson & Wales will pass a culinary student with a broken hollandaise. JWU does not give the employees the instruments they need for their job, very little flexibility to help the students, and few teachers keep up with trends or the quality experience with the high standards of operations in the hospitality and tourism industry. Please look at how many JWU graduates with Michelin Stars vs. their competitors like the CIA or Le Cordon Bleu. 

 I'm not saying don't work here and earn your pay. Everyone needs a roof over the head and food on the table. Just be prepared to have your hands tied regarding certain situations that may question character of the company.

job_title: Adminsitraive Assistant in North Miami, FL
pros: Leadership/Management Team Work/Life Balance Team Environment Trainings and Workshops Days Off/Vacation/Holidays
cons: Low Salary Hard to Advance

pros: The students and co-workers I worked with were great!
cons: Nothing I can think of

job_title: Assistant Professor in North Miami, FL
pros: Teaching experience & student engagement
cons: Toxic culture & bad leadership

job_title: Graduate Student Assistant in Providence, RI
pros: They are really nice and always there to lend you a helping hand if you need one. They have a great work environment and the people there make you feel welcomed by throwing Birthday parties to even having free food and drinks. The job although it was tiring mentally it was rewarding at times helping other students.
cons: Speaking to parents who do not treat you well. Students who have no respect at times. A lot of emails and phone calls.

review_title: This university is a circus that’s about to close down
pros: Benefits for employees that make it
cons: University seems it’s in financial crisis. Has closed TWO campuses, has let go of hundreds of staff. The top lady in charge, the CEO (BTW it’s not John Bowen) does not have a heart and does not care for students OR diversity. Leadership from past decades were amazing but this lady is tone deaf (to minorities or anyone who thinks differently than her) and her cold self centered leadership style is horrible. She does not lead as a non-profit leader and there is nothing to show otherwise. A quick search on the internet will be a great tool to research what students, faculty and staff have to say.

job_title: Campus Safety Officer in Charlotte, NC
pros: Beautiful Campus, The university is located near all the center city attractions.
cons: The school continues to grow in a positive direction and currently adding more career options for the students .

pros:
Great work life balance
Generous time off
cons: Pay is extremely low and management does not seem to want to pay anyone higher.

pros: The work changed daily so we never got bored and I got to work with my closest friends. It was the best office environment I’ve ever been in. So many great perks like occasional free lunches during tours and events. Such a friendly and welcoming environment and the work kept me active because I was always giving tours of the city/campus.
cons: The pay could’ve been a little higher, but for a work study position, this is more than UNH pays (which is the most expensive state school in the country iirc.)

review_title: School takes advantage of student workers
pros: Don't have much to say here unless you're a student who is looking for an underpaid, minimum wage, and convenient job on campus.
cons: My supervisors were constantly disorganized and couldn't answer basic questions relating to my position. The full-time salaried employees are unpaid and haven't received raises in over 5 years, not even adjustments for cost of living. And even after my bosses gave me an outstanding performance review, HR did not give me a raise until 3 months after the review was conducted and my boss had to fight for me, after all of that they decided to give me a 10 cent raise, what a slap in the face. I was more mature than the 2 middle-aged women I worked with, who would constantly fight with each other and gossip behind each other's backs. Since the school is a non-profit, they legally can opt-out of the student employees paying into unemployment, which screwed over hundreds if not thousands of student employees during covid. If you are a student. you're better off finding a job at the mall.

pros: Good hours and good management, good benefits.
cons: Slow to change company policies

pros: Good location, decent facilities, fairly inexpensive for students.
cons: JWU doesn't care in the least about employees. The "raises" are about half the inflation rate and they spontaneously eliminated the 401k 6% match for 2021. It was a tough year for everyone, but they've made it clear that you can accept being shorted or leave. Administration seems to be turning over every couple weeks, I can't even count how many people have been Provost in the last few years. Some schools are a community, JWU is clearly a business first.

pros: I love the enviroment,, I loved the job performance
cons: not enough hours I wanted to work more hous

job_title: Student Admissions Officer in Denver, CO
pros: Great coworkers, excellent benefits, and people who really love the school.
cons: Small campus and run by another campus who didn’t always understand the needs of Denver’s campus.

pros:
Benefits
university schedule (usually)
Parking is included
Friendly coworkers
cons:
benefits are expensive
unorganzied
Unflexible work schedule
Low pay for amount of work

pros: JWU has been quick to respond to the needs of faculty and students during the pandemic and included technical supports.
cons: Remote teaching isn't the best, but JWU has been quick to come back to in-person learning as soon as possible.

job_title: Certified Athletic Trainer in Providence, RI
pros:
Pro- sports culture
Amazing students
Decent facilities
Free gym access
Good health benefits
cons:
Split campuses
Poor pay
Budget cuts and layoffs

pros: I work with wonderful colleagues on a team focused on the growth of Johnson & Wales
cons: Currently working remote and have not had the opportunity of working in the office since my start date.

job_title: Director of Athletics in Charlotte, NC
pros: Culture of acceptance and good people
cons: Leadership is inconsistent and lacks vision

review_title: American educational model; McUniversity wink, wink
pros: Interesting co-workers on campus; providence is a nice city, walking distnce
cons: Admissions recruitment exploits families charging harvard tuition and delivers community college teaching (except culinary) untenured, often unqualified adjunct and FT faculty

pros: Wonderful place to work for.
cons: No cons. I truly enjoyed my time there.

pros: Great people! Friendly staff and great benefits
cons: Nothing in particular. Need more accounting students

job_title: Student Business Assistant in Providence, RI
pros:
-work with students 
-help fund clubs/orgs
-easy work and great networking
cons:
-restricted access to certain programs that should be available 
-pay is set at minimum wage with a 25 cent raise every year

pros: Full time year round, 365 days
cons: The University is not financially stable, despite the appearances they try to give.

review_title: Great family culture  with work life balance
pros: Colleagues and managers in genuinely supportive. Students are hard working and most really appreciate the assistance and effort in helping them. Lots of opportunities to get involved and make a difference in the lives of students, staff & faculty, parents and the community.
cons: It is a great place to work, there really are no unique cons to the institution. Like other colleges and universities who have had to cut back because of enrollment, there are budget restrictions that limit raises and upward mobility.

pros: Very accommodating, great place to work, relaxed atmosphere, very nice people to work with, teams are great and bosses are understanding.
cons: Raises are not great, but what you give up in money you gain in comfort of relaxed workplace.

review_title: AWESOME PLACE!!! So sad the North Miami Campus closed
job_title: Safety & Security in North Miami, FL
pros: All inclusive, veteran friendly, family feeling job!!!
cons: The campus closed!!! It was the best job I ever had!!!

job_title: Experiential Education & Career Advisor in Providence, RI
pros: Great university to work for
cons: Time management and communication has been an issue

pros: Great team members - collaborative and supportive
cons:
lack of opportunity for advancement; limited opportunity for continuing education

management not in touch with employees 

can feel a bit like an assembly line

pros:

Nice people

It’s a good place to work

pros: Supportive team and good benefits
cons: Unclear communication between management and team members

pros: Great atmosphere, co-workers. No micro-managing. Work-life balance!
cons: Providence is not the most exciting place to live in

pros: Excellent benefit, culture, diversity, students, and employees.
cons: Not many opportunities for growth

pros: Great benefits, great people. Strong Athletic department with good leadership.
cons: Disconnect between athletics and academics. Position comes with a lot of additional duties.

pros: Very family oriented, great benefits and great people.
cons: I really do not have any cons

job_title: Reference and Instruction Librarian in Providence, RI
pros:
students are passionate and motivated
staff and faculty fight hard to provide top notch support
cons: as with many academic institutions, resources are not limitless

review_title: Student Assistant in Finance JWU Providence
pros: This position was a great first experience working in an Accounting Environment
cons: There's a fair bit of clerical work included

review_title: Great place to work while going to school
job_title: Graduate Student Assistant in Providence, RI
pros: Flexible hours, part-time or full-time positions
cons: Can't think of any cons

job_title: Front Desk Receptionist in Providence, RI
pros: it was a good job
cons: nothing to complain about really

job_title: Employer Relations Manager in Providence, RI
pros: Get to work with students, Good benefits
cons: Understaffed in a lot of areas

pros: Yes, Good place to work, very nice
cons: Nothing was wrong with this place

review_title: Great Education, Great staff, faculty, & students
job_title: Director of International Student Services in Providence, RI
pros: The staff, faculty, and students at JWU are diverse & friendly.
cons: International student recruitment and enrollment was crushed by the pandemic.

pros: Benefits and PTO, career advancement
cons: Politics but overall no big cons

job_title: Assistant Director of Student Activities in Miami, FL
pros: Great work environment and benefits packages.
cons: No cons - it is truly a great place to work.

job_title: Assistant Professor in North Miami, FL
pros: Positive Reputation, Longevity, Culinary Program, and Hospitality
cons: Poor Leadership, Culture Programs, Not Innovative, Unwillingness to Change

review_title: Not cracked up to what it entails
pros: Getting to know most of the staff
cons: The pay is really bad.

review_title: Learn to value your most important asset:  your people
pros: The people that do the work on the ground are great
cons: Leadership leaves something to be desired

pros: I get to work at sporting events.
cons: The pay is very low.

review_title: Looking to Evolve, but Culture of Disrespect and Distrust Holding it Back
pros: The people who work at JWU are, in general, great. Nice facilities for staff. Faculty care about the students and want to ensure their success. Passionate professionals at the entry and mid-level. Institution encourages and actively supports work life balance.
cons: Administration encourages and rewards unprofessional behavior and culture of disrespect from students, parents, and upper level management. Benefits are lacking for an institution of higher education.  Pay is below average for comparable institutions. Students and parents are rude and culture rewards it in hopes of keeping students enrolled. No clear vision - institution throws anything out there in hopes it will work.  Culture prides itself in saying it cares for it employees, but the reality does not reflect this (e.g. pay, benefits, treatment of professionals by upper level administration). General lack of flexibility in the workplace. Lack of vision, which leads to staff focusing on day-to-day tasks rather than assisting in helping the institution grow and evolve. Run like a business from the top down, rather than an institution of higher learning.

pros: Campus leadership, students want to learn
cons: The North Miami campus is closing.

pros: great students! hard workers and career driven
cons: adjuncts are not connected to the larger JWU community so it can feel isolating

pros: great benefits, rewarding work, good people
cons: heavy workload at times, but I'm happy to have meaningful work

pros: Great place to study and go for grad school.
cons: None that I can think of.

job_title: Front Office Manager in Providence, RI
pros: meeting people, cool environment, helps when getting a job.
cons: unorganized workspace, needs improvement, lack of communication

pros: The people I worked with made all the difference.
cons: Not alot of opportunity for growth in field

review_title: Big Brother Is Watching Your Every Move
pros: Early release Friday's in the summer, Xmas vacation without having to use up your own time, Free parking.
cons: Compared to pay at other colleges, especially the state schools, you will feel like a grad student.  They pay on average is about 20K less than a state school.  The inbreeding at the higher levels of administration is incestuous and they make a lot of money.  If you are not part of the "in crowd" without certain political connections or family name recognition, you will not (ever) move up the ladder.  They have oppressive computer policies and actively monitor all your emails and correspondence.  No kidding, they are listening through the walls.  Conform with their hyper vigilant gestapo like policies or you are out of here (I have seen it happen), no matter how valuable you may be to the "company", and I mean company (not university).  This place is run more like a dictatorship than in institution of higher education.  The 1%'ers run the show and thats it like it or not.  Its there way or the highway.  They will find a way to get rid of you.  If you are a student and your parents have enough money, you should be ok as long as your behavior doesn't make the morning papers.  The media machine at JWU does a great job at keeping things quiet.

job_title: Social Media Coordinator in Providence, RI
pros: Free grad school, great people and lots of PTO
cons: No room for growth, no salaries

job_title: Workstudy Student in North Miami, FL
pros:
Nice employers and co-workers
Basically getting paid to do homework
cons:
Pay sucks
Can work only 12 hours a week

pros: Great benefits and work-life balance
cons: The top-down management style does not support high performing employees

pros: breaks for holidays, great work environment
cons: little pay, little hours, disorganized

job_title: Assistant Director, Student Involvement in North Miami, FL
pros: Supportive community at the North Miami Campus, opportunities to try new programs, flexibility in scheduling
cons: Closing of the campus was not people-focused or supportive from the Providence campus; processes are a bit disjointed and convoluted across the various campuses.

pros: Great work environment, good pay, great scheduling
cons: Closing my campus after 2020-21 year

pros: Great time off and vacation
cons: Busy course load for faculty

review_title: JWU is a life-changer, and not in a good way....
pros: I worked for JWU for 10 years.  5 of them were really great.  Early release on summer Fridays was awesome.  Administration really seemed to care about the staff and faculty.   We were given the freedom to develop new programs for the students and suggest changes in the status quo that would improve the student experience.  We felt that our voices were heard.  The last 5 years were abysmal and that experience needs to go under the "Cons" section.
cons: JWU Denver underwent a slow but steady change in upper management.  Once that change was complete, with a new president and subsequently, all new faces in management, JWU stopped being concerned about the student experience. Instead, the focus was on how to do our jobs with fewer staff & faculty members, fewer resources and less money.  Gone were the days of spending enough time with students to do any good; in fact, we were directed to spend as little time with students as possible.  The current leadership at JWU is a joke.

review_title: Senior leaders control, use fear tactics, and don't listen
pros:
good benefits
food
free parking
tuition assistance for children
peer friendships
cons:
top leaders focus only on money, not people
raises for top leaders, low pay for faculty
lip service - don't act on employees ideas
no knowledge sharing (silos)
lack of sincere recognition
inconsistent managerial styles, incompetence
lack of real, earned doctorates at top leader level
lack of strategic use of human resources, under appreciation of talent
weak support and little resources for development of people
top leaders are not available, don't know what's going on, don't make themselves available to students, staff, faculty for feedback.
very low trust culture: people afraid to speak truth
untrained deans and chairs

review_title: Run don't walk away from this company.
pros: Free classes for you and your dependents.  Free parking for your automobile.  Continuing education opportunities (Master and Doctorate). Early release on Fridays in the summer. Winter break gives you at least a week of vacation in addition to 2 weeks of vacation after completion of your first year.  (And trust me you'll need/want it). Cake job if you are faculty...especially avoid other departments like the plague...specifically anything in student services (res life, career development, registrar, financial aid)
cons: The nepotism that exists at the University is terrible.  There are people in senior levels of administration (Vice President) that are completely incompetent. Turnover in many departments is at 70% yet no one seems to care or investigate why people are leaving in droves.  Very sexist. Sexual harrassment in some cases is handled swiftly and surely but completely ignored in other cases and allowed to continue. Depending on the department you work in and the position you have you are expected to work 70 plus hours a week, with no comp time or bonus for a good job.

review_title: Networking and getting to know professors on a personal level was a great experience
pros: I worked for JWU for 2 years as an Office Assistant for the School of Business formerly known as the College of Management. COM sounds so much better than SOB. Just saying!....But overall I enjoyed my time there working with Linda and all the Business professors.  The environment is relaxed and friendly. As long as you got  your work done efficiently, you had a lot of free time.
cons: Nothing major sticks out. The only part that is more on myself than the university is I got a wage raise once I worked for more than a year but then ended up having the same pay rate as new comers due to the minimum wage raise.  I wish that they had reflected my earned raise during that transition.

review_title: Johnson & Wales provides an excellent atmosphere to create memories; with professors who care deeply about each student
pros: An intimate campus giving rise to memories of days when education was not a factory but an individually selected experience. Teaching at JWU allows contact with each student to be ultimately the more significant relationship. Faculty truly puts students first and works to encourage all to excell. It is the reward of being involved and making a difference.
cons: To me the only downside is in being an Adjunct and not a full professor. Wishing that I had stayed on the course in being an educator instead of selecting to be a businessman.

review_title: JWU a place to work for both me and you.  It feels like home, if you like living at home.
pros: The University invests both in its students and its employee's.  This is a very large feat for a University that still tries and feel like a small university.
cons: Sometimes great ideas are squashed when they come from several layers below managment.  Decision take to long to make and things tend to be very repeative

job_title: Banquet Captain/Fellowship Program in Warwick, RI
pros: I had the experience of working for the University as a student, at the Radisson Airport Hotel. The professional staff (non-students) who worked there were some of the nicest and most competent people I've had the pleasure of working with. And the perks as a student are great. Aside from the three meals a day, you work with peers and managers who understand the heavy work load of a working student. I always felt such a strong sense of team, and it made us great at what we did!
cons: Pay is not fabulous, but the perks help alleviate some of that strain. Not a ton of variation, days are pretty routine.

job_title: Teaching Assistant and Resident Assistant in Denver, CO
pros: As a student, it provides easy access to your job from the dorm room.  All jobs on campus include a scholarship and/or an hourly pay.
cons: They treat the students like crap.  Every department I have worked in has lost the vision of the positions they offer.  As a student assistant, resident assistant, and teaching assistant, we are students first.  The University officials guarantee that they will be flexible with hours and work load, but in the end, our grades are failing because they don't allow time for you to be a student, and an employee.

job_title: Administrative Assistant At Student Financial Services in Providence, RI
pros: working as a student of the university, you are given a scholarship and they give you a certain amount of credit to cover the cost of a summer course (the remaining balance is on you) and you get to live in the dorms for free if you stay during the summer time to work for the university.
cons: older generation of employees who treated students as if they were incompetent of doing any work. there was no type of trust at all between the student workers and management though when they needed something to get done urgently it would be thrown on your desk without a "please" or "thank you". after a year and a half, i quit because i felt so underappreciated it was affecting my mental health.

review_title: A good organization to work for and best part are the benefits.
pros: Most valuable benefit is/was the tuition waver for employees but they also off 401K match and really seem to care about employees. Seems they do as much as they can.
cons: I feel each year I was there things such as holiday bonuses or department holiday parties were getting smaller or combining departments to stretch it out. With the economy in the past I'm not sure how many companies still do this so I wasn't complaining.

pros: On-campus, ability to interact with staff, and professional experience. You get out what you put in, and managers will see what you're capable of, and trust you accordingly.
cons: Pay, pay increases, and scholarship is factored into your "cap amount", so if you're already at the cap for jwu aid, you forfeit the scholarship. Also, if they see you're a Student Assistant they may take one of your other scholarships away so you end up paying the same amount. They should do away with the scholarship and just pay more, and give the students the option to overturn to tuition if they want.

review_title: It was a big learning experience with phases of work load and absolutely nothing to do
pros: The job teaches professionalism for young students and how to work in a business office and conduct oneself in a professional manner
cons: For a student assistant job, the department expects a lot from you. Many times it would feel like the student is doing far more work then the regular employees.

pros: A positive environment. Faculty and administration show a genuine interest in every student they meet. Most everyone I worked with consistently went above and beyond to help students to achieve their educational goals.
cons: Normal cons of employment in higher education. A great place to work but... the local Universities are tied to a larger system, creating a bit of extra red tape.

pros: A place to 'learn a lot' and then take those skills and move onto another organization who will pay better and allow for professional and personal growth.
cons: High stress workplace. Inept management (from CEO on down to many department managers). They only promote inept people. No opportunity for people who do the actual work to grow and prosper. No opportunity for professional development.  Too much nepotism. Declining enrollment - not a stable workplace right now.

review_title: JWU Denver: dedicated employees, awesome students, unfortunate leadership
pros: The students, staff, and faculty. The people working on the front lines truly cared about student success and everyone knows each other.
cons: Administration and leadership were ineffective.  University decisions and appointments were made unethically (i.e. who is easiest/cheapest to hire vs. who is the best person for the job).  I was not a victim of this practice, but watching it happen at every level was extremely disappointing when you want the best for students.

job_title: Technical Support Assistant in Providence, RI
pros: Flexible hours for students, great customer service learning experience, learn about most commonly used audio visual systems.
cons: Overly complicated system for time off or calling in sick, some of the assistance offices are under geared or to small to fully operate successfully without it being over crowded with people during busy hours.

job_title: Campus Safety Officer in Denver, CO
pros: A beautiful and historical campus with a small student body. You'll get to know the students, and be a guiding figure if you choose to. You'll be well compensated for the additional hours you spend on the job. Plenty of overtime.
cons: Always short staffed, High turnover, expect to account for every moment of your time.

review_title: Johnson and Wales University provided me with an excellent foundation upon which i built my hospitality career!
pros: I was hired an the Faculty Instructor for the hotel school internship program upon completion of my BS Degree in Hospitality Management. This position lead me to my Regional Training Manager position with Hilton Inns Inc. a division of Hilton Hotels Corporation.
cons: There are no cons to mention

pros:
-$360.00 scholarship if you maintain full-time student status in Johnson and Wales University.
-$1000.00 scholarship if you select summer course and also work as TSA in JWU.
-14 food swipes and $50.00 free dollar if you select summer course and also work as TSA in JWU.
cons: -TSAs in Downcity Campus are in charge of buildings in a long distance, and TSAs have to work to it.

pros: Johnson & Wales has the best of the traditional brick and mortar university world combined with the career focused education offered by many online schools. Their approach to the work place is also a hybrid. Benefits are outstanding, especially medical insurance.
cons: It is still academia, with some departments having Harvard expectations but no budget.

review_title: This College is wonderful and teaches professionalism and management skills through real life events.
pros: Understanding that you are still a student and will make mistakes. Also, there are so many connections through the faculty that will aid you with jobs, opportunities, and events.
cons: There is always a ceiling of progression for students. We can only grow so much before having to find a new job in the industry.

pros: The people at Johnson & Wales are very nice and considerate, and the scheduling was very flexible as they worked with me to ensure I had enough hours.
cons: Organization of the office was less than ideal, dealing with appointments was unorganized, and there were very few resources outside of my own notes and knowledge.

pros: JWU has a great staff and is a wonderful school. Flexibility to use your own style of teaching was acceptable as long as you were following the curriculum that the department had standardized on.
cons: Not much in negativity other than some of the courses were held in older buildings where the heating was out of control on warm days. Thermostat read 85+ degrees in the classroom at times.

review_title: Educate and counsel students on financial planning.
job_title: Financial Planning Counelor in Charlotte, NC
pros: Student Engagement, Offering solutions, Being in a position to encourage and guide
cons: Delivering unpleasant news, such loss of funding, or ineligibility for financial assistance due to circumstances.

pros: Everyone was willing to help me out, and as a student here it was nice to work in a familiar enviornment
cons: They did not provide me with everything I needed to make my time at this job as effective as it could. I didn't have a set room so I was always bouncing around.

job_title: Instructor, College Or University in Providence, RI
pros: J&W offer the tools and support for all faculty to work in best conditions posible. The facility si well design to accomplish this goal
cons: J7W instructors need to understand that students are customers.. They need to teach them a professional attitude not to earn a Ego after graduate..

review_title: If I could do it again, I would choose still choose JWU!
pros: The university cares about its employees and students and the benefits are excellent. Most employees are very grateful to be working here and many have been employed 10 + years.
cons: Career path planning does not exist.

job_title: Resident Assistant in North Miami, FL
pros: The scholarship, the teammates, the perks are all pros. Small school so there are not too many pros
cons: The management, the rules & the policies are all a bit ridiculous. The management is very uneven, holding up rules one day that they ignore the next.

pros: Accommodating with class schedules, vacations. Able to know what companies are looking for, great people. School scholarship, great networking opportunities, if you are employed over the summer you are able to get free housing and also meals.
cons: Can't really get promoted as student assistant, the pay is not that good, it goes with minimum wage. Benefits are what you would expect as student assistant job.

pros: My team was very nice, personable, and always willing to help. They were flexible with my hours.
cons: There were not many benefits for being a student assistant. The scholarship went down. However, we were offered housing and meals over the summer.

pros: The benefits of working as an office assistant were great: annual pay raises, stipends as a scholarship position, occasionally time to do homework, networking opportunities
cons: Didn't see many cons besides occasionally having to deal with needy faculty/staff

review_title: JWU is a great place to work
pros: The people you work with are fantastic individuals - always ready to help.  Communication is good from the top down.  It is a great opportunity.
cons: There are no cons to the job.  If you enjoy what you do and work hard, keep the proper perspective and there will be nothing negative to say.

review_title: Partially Good with a lot of benefits
pros: Really good environment. Students are awesome, and the rest of the staff is helpful. A lot of benefits that could be helpful such as food, parking garage.
cons: If money is your motivation, this is not your place to be. Management is lacking skills.

pros: The students are enthusiastic about their specialties. Additionally, they are friendly and service oriented. One of the graduates warmed my heart by saying that she wouldn't have gotten her job if it hadn't been for my teaching her to write.
cons: One of the staff is not fit for her job.

review_title: Not an Overall Bad Place to Work
job_title: Technology Student Assistant in New York, NY
pros: Flexible Hours,Scholarship factored into tuition, On-Campus, Easy Commute, Faculty and Staff Interaction, Friendly and Personable Supervisors/Managers
cons: Not a Lot Of Holiday Time Off, Initial Pay and Pay Increases are not commensurate to the amount of work put in

job_title: Office of Student Activities/Front Desk Work Study in Pleasanton, CA
pros: The Office of Student Activities staff is made up of a lot of students that are fun to work with.
cons: Hypocritical with work staff. The pro staff creates rules. Allows staff to break them but warns other staff for breaking.

review_title: Good co-workers and want to do good by students
pros:
Non-Profit, not as stressful as corporate world.
Great work calendar
Good work life balance
Good salaries if you're director or higher
or Professor
cons:
Almost no room for promotion - it's mostly title changes, becase people stay for a very long time
It's not a challenging environment - so it's a good place if you want to retire

pros:
-As a student employee you are already on campus so commuting is fast.
-Management is VERY understanding and works to accommodate you.
-Your surrounded by great people who really know what they are doing
cons: -Not fantastic pay. However, it is ok because the job includes a generous scholarship.

pros: The university provides a lot of benefits and is very fair when it comes to working around class time.
cons: To ensure students aren't overworking and still spending time on school work your working hours are limited depending on how high of a position you have. Not really a con unless you like working a lot.

pros: Excellent benefits; great health insurance, PTO, and sick days.
cons: Terrible wages; pay is not commensurate to the amount of work, education, and level of responsibility one has in this position.

review_title: JWU Charlotte inspires me to work harder for the students.
pros: Johnson and Wales Charlotte offers its employees strong  leadership, opportunities to sample gourmet food, great colleagues, and a beautiful location in the heart of Uptown.
cons: The office space is a bit confined. There are not as many opportunities for advancement as one might enjoy elsewhere.

job_title: Adjunct Professor in North Miami, FL
pros: The school provides excellent access to teach, mentor, and reach out to the new generation of college students interested in culinary, hospitality, and sports/entertainment management careers.
cons: Hope that they can continue to keep admissions up!

review_title: Great University Great Place to work on the Denver Campus
pros: A very collaborative with co workers. Newly renovated student and staff facilities. Half day on Fridays during the summer. Student Focused.
cons: Occasional multi campus decision making on the departmental level can be tough. It does not happen that much, but can be an issue.

pros: they work with you to schedule hours so if you have to pick up kids or anything you can
cons: management does not know what it is doing. treat employees like they work for burger king

job_title: Student Activities Office Assistant in North Miami, FL
pros: accommodates class schedule, flexible with school breaks. Many weekend events to host and set up for
cons: No scholarship, no over time unless told by supervisor

job_title: Special Events Assistant in Charlotte, NC
pros:
Very great job while in school. I gained a lot of experience. 
The events you work will be for students, donors,and companies.
You will get the opportunity to network with a diverse group of people.
cons:
The pay is very low.
You are only allowed to work 9.5 hours a week.

review_title: Good to Attend and Work For
pros: It's very convenient to go to school and work for the university you're attending. Very flexible hours and understanding of other commitments.
cons: As a student assistant you work for minimum wage and have maximum and minimum hours which means a consistent but small pay check.

pros: Great place to work to learn the fundamentals of cooking with minimal pressure
cons: Management and co-workers are spotty. Some are great, some are grossly incompetent.

review_title: Very good overall, but limited experience.
pros: You get to impact whether a student chooses JWU as their college.
cons: Security meant only basic excel files instead of the originally planned sql database.

pros: I really enjoyed working at the Harbourside campus library in RI. All the librarians were very kind and supportive. You can study during slow hours and also read any book you want.
cons: I don't think there is any downside working at JWU. I really think they were great

pros:
- Flexible hours accordance with office requirement
- Scholarship upon employment every term 
- Summer benefits, such us meal plans.
- Convenience to public commercial and transportation area
cons:
Limited opportunities to meet new people, getting involved with the world outside.
However, we do have 4 campuses locating in different states.

review_title: A professional university to gain experience from
pros: Everyone is professional and tries to give the best customer support to current and prospective students.
cons: The only challenge is that you deal with students that can get difficult when you try to enforce school policies.

job_title: Front Desk Recepionist in Charlotte, NC
pros: Very nice people, good coworkers and great work life balance. Manager and bosses are very kind and helpful.
cons: Sometimes the work can be pretty boring, not always working every hour of the day but I guess thats a good thing!

review_title: You might want to look somewhere else
pros: health benefits are great. except vision.
cons: Lousy management. Stacked with overpaid execs and not enough worker bees. Not enough room for growth

review_title: JWU is an amazing place to work with a very friendly staff.
pros: Friendly atmosphere, four day work weeks, reduced tuition for staff member's children, helpful coworkers,.
cons: Work study students only get 10 hours a week.

pros: Great people to work with; great pay; very enjoyable work
cons:
Adjuncts are definitely 2nd class employees, asked to do 2x as much work as F/T employees but not given the same perks.
Adjuncts are rarely promoted to F/T status, though they tell you otherwise

pros:
Education
Training
Development
Networking

cons:
Ego Trips
Power Hungry

job_title: Anonymous Employee in North Miami, FL
pros: Terrific benefit package including very low employee contribution for health and dental coverage and education benefits
cons: Raises not based on performance - everyone gets the same thing and that is not much.  Good people leave and poor performers remain.

pros: The colleagues in my immediate department were wonderful to work with
cons: upper management is unprofessional, not supportive and do not advocate for advancement or promotion from within. There is little to no room for growth.

pros:
*Fast-paced environment
*Opportunity to meet a lot of different people
cons: *Pay rate is so-so (not high)

pros: Very Nice working office environment and good people. Very helpful to students from all perspectives. Challenging, competitive, a perfect match for anyone that is willing to perform highly.
cons: schedule is very odd. Benefit is not very good.

pros:
top tier  medical,dental,vision, 401k match, yearly bonus.yearly employee apprication Day
employees no charge for undergrad classes except for books, Grad school classes; employees pay a percentage the class cost.
cons: low pay grades compared to other private university's in the state.

pros: Flexible work schedule, co workers are great
cons: Pay is awful, no room from growth, school is overspending on everything, student retention is at an all time low

pros: Very flexible and understanding of each employee.
cons:
Some older employees are very stuck in their ways.
Some lower management positions seem to have been given based on "who ya know"

review_title: Student Assistant, great benefits, minimum wage.
pros: Great benefits, scholarship every trimester, work 20 hours a week, flexible hours, free housing over the summer.
cons: May have to sacrifice classes to fit in 20 hours a week. Pays minimum wage.

pros: Helping students transition from college to career, co-workers/family atmosphere, employee benefits, being able to do what I love - teaching in the classroom.
cons: None. I love my job!

job_title: Student Assistant in East Providence, RI
pros: The environment around is nice and friendly with less pressure.
